identificationModule.briefTitle: Effect of Intensive Motor Rehabilitation in Subacute Stroke Patient
identificationModule.officialTitle: Effect of Intensive Motor Rehabilitation in Subacute Stroke Patient

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Early stroke rehabilitation is known to be an effective and essential therapy in gaining functional independence and preventing complications. However, there was no consensus of proper amount of motor rehabilitation in stroke patients. In this study, the investigators investigated the effects of the intensive motor rehabilitation during subacute phase to improve motor function at 6 months after onset in patients with first-ever strokes.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
Intensive cognitive rehabilitation group

- physical and occupational therapy for 3 hours on every working day for 2 weeks

interventions.name: Intensive motor rehabilitation
interventions.description: Intensive motor rehabilitation during subacute stroke phase

primaryOutcomes.measure: Upper limb score of Fugl-Meyer assessment
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Change of upper limb score of Fugl-Meyer assessment after intensive motor rehabilitation for 4 weeks

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Acute first-ever stroke
* Upper limb score of Fugl-Meyer assessment at 7 days after onset : 25\~84

Exclusion Criteria:

* Transient ischemic stroke
* Joint contracture of affected upper extremity
